"alicloud disk" probably it's something like gp3, and it's "throughput-oriented high-latency network disk". I guess it's just too high-latency for BSC. 

make integration
./build/bin/integration print_stages

> "alicloud disk" probably it's something like gp3, and it's "throughput-oriented high-latency network disk". I guess it's just too high-latency for BSC. > > make integration ./build/bin/integration print_stages ```shell INFO[02-10|13:53:35.806] [Snapshots] Blocks Stat blocks=24000k indices=24000k alloc=2.3GB sys=2.4GB Note: prune_at doesn't mean 'all data before were deleted' - it just mean stage.Prune function were run to this block. Because 1 stage may prune multiple data types to different prune distance. stage_at prune_at Snapshots 25211804 0 Headers 25466663 0 BlockHashes 25466663 0 Bodies 25466663 0 Senders 25466663 0 Execution 25466663 24904179 Translation 0 0 HashState 25466663 0 IntermediateHashes 25466663 24904179 AccountHistoryIndex 25211804 0 StorageHistoryIndex 25211804 0 LogIndex 25211804 0 CallTraces 25211804 24904179 TxLookup 25211804 24000000 Finish 25211804 0 -- prune distance: blocks.v2: blocks=23999999, segments=23999999, indices=23999999 history.v3: false, idx steps: 0.00, lastMaxTxNum=0->0, lastBlockInSnap=0 sequence: EthTx=3933466482, NonCanonicalTx=48275 in db: first header 22681700, last header 25466663, first body 22681700, last body 25466663 -- ``` Which type of disk should I choose.

iops - it's throughput, not latency.

`print_stages` shows that you are in progress of sync - big jump from 25211804 to 25466663.
after this jump finish - I advise you take a look on the size of next jump, if it's smaller - then after several such jumps you will get in sync. if not, then likely you need disk with lower latency.

> iops - it's throughput, not latency. > > `print_stages` shows that you are in progress of sync - big jump from 25211804 to 25466663. after this jump finish - I advise you take a look on the size of next jump, if it's smaller - then after several such jumps you will get in sync. if not, then likely you need disk with lower latency. ok got it,why do the bsc sync so slowly,that thing didt happen in ethereum mainnet, may be bsc network should need low latency disk?

`GP3` and `IO2` has high write latency and hence not suitable for `heavy` chain like polygon & bsc. you can check iops with fio on these disk. another work around is to `raid-0` a few volume together.
My suggestion is not to use cloud disks. I donâ€™t have this situation with aws nvme. I guess Ali also has similar machines.
